title: Hardware Information
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Connector Printers Label Printers Cash Drawers Scanners Barcode Scanners NCR SCO tri-Light CONNECTOR The Connector, developed by K3, is a Linux-based (x86_64) server device that serves as a point-of-sale hardware station. It allows for browser-based printing and can connect to a cash drawer. It is important to note that an Ethernet connection is required, and it must be connected to the network through a CAT5e cable or higher. The Connector is compatible with two types of printers: K3-manufactured printers and Epson T88V printers. Additionally, any Epson-compatible cash drawer connected to the same printers is also supported. PRINTERS The K3 Thermal Receipt Printer is a 40-column receipt printer, similar to an Epson T88, that is manufactured by K3. It requires a serial connection (9-pin) and features an onboard Drawer Kicker, which can be used to activate the connected cash drawer. The Epson T88V is another standard printer that requires a serial connection (25-pin) and also includes an onboard Drawer Kicker for the connected cash drawer. It's important to note that specific dip switch settings are necessary for the TM88V, which can be found in the installation instructions for the printer. The ODP333 is a 40-column receipt printer, similar to an Epson T88, that is manufactured by Aures. For this printer, baud settings may need to be adjusted and logos must be flashed to the printer memory. LABEL PRINTERS The Citizen CL-S521 is the sole label printer that is supported and uses thermal direct printing. It's important to note that while other label printers that support the ZPL language and feature a serial port may function properly, they are not directly supported by K3. CASH DRAW K3 Cash Drawer - This is manufactured by K3 using an Epson Compatible Drawer Kick port. Any Epson-compatible Cash Drawer. SCANNERS To ensure the proper functioning of any scanner used with the POS software, it must be able to support and run "Keyboard Wedge" via USB, PS/2, or Bluetooth. We recommend testing the scanner with any barcode labels in use, whether pre-printed on products or printed in-house, as well as scanning the receipt barcode to ensure that the output precisely matches the data represented by the barcode. To run a simple test, scan the barcode into a text editor such as Notepad or TextEdit and compare the data to the barcode. Please note that some options within Imagine enable simultaneous printing to both label and receipt printers, such as gift receipt/label printing. If only one printer is being used, the connector will attempt to print to the only available device if these options are selected, which may result in random characters appearing on either labels or receipts. If this occurs, please check the settings within Imagine and use only the available device. BARCODE SCANNER Imagine has been found to work seamlessly with both USB and Bluetooth scanners that are set to keyboard wedge mode. However, as there are numerous types of platforms, browsers, connection types, and driver requirements, K3 cannot provide an exhaustive list of the compatible scanner makes and models. NCR SCO TRI-LIGHT The NCR SCO tri-light requires the SCO Agent to be running to function. This can be installed by your local K3 representative or by contacting your local K3 Support.
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Connector
  • Printers
  • Label Printers
  • Cash Drawers
  • Scanners
  • Barcode Scanners
  • NCR SCO tri-Light

CONNECTOR

The Connector, developed by K3, is a Linux-based (x86_64) server device that serves as a point-of-sale hardware station. It allows for browser-based printing and can connect to a cash drawer.

It is important to note that an Ethernet connection is required, and it must be connected to the network through a CAT5e cable or higher.

The Connector is compatible with two types of printers: K3-manufactured printers and Epson T88V printers. Additionally, any Epson-compatible cash drawer connected to the same printers is also supported.


PRINTERS

The K3 Thermal Receipt Printer is a 40-column receipt printer, similar to an Epson T88, that is manufactured by K3. It requires a serial connection (9-pin) and features an onboard Drawer Kicker, which can be used to activate the connected cash drawer.

The Epson T88V is another standard printer that requires a serial connection (25-pin) and also includes an onboard Drawer Kicker for the connected cash drawer. It's important to note that specific dip switch settings are necessary for the TM88V, which can be found in the installation instructions for the printer.

The ODP333 is a 40-column receipt printer, similar to an Epson T88, that is manufactured by Aures. For this printer, baud settings may need to be adjusted and logos must be flashed to the printer memory.


LABEL PRINTERS

The Citizen CL-S521 is the sole label printer that is supported and uses thermal direct printing.

It's important to note that while other label printers that support the ZPL language and feature a serial port may function properly, they are not directly supported by K3.


CASH DRAW

K3 Cash Drawer - This is manufactured by K3 using an Epson Compatible Drawer Kick port.

Any Epson-compatible Cash Drawer.


SCANNERS

To ensure the proper functioning of any scanner used with the POS software, it must be able to support and run "Keyboard Wedge" via USB, PS/2, or Bluetooth. We recommend testing the scanner with any barcode labels in use, whether pre-printed on products or printed in-house, as well as scanning the receipt barcode to ensure that the output precisely matches the data represented by the barcode.

To run a simple test, scan the barcode into a text editor such as Notepad or TextEdit and compare the data to the barcode.

Please note that some options within Imagine enable simultaneous printing to both label and receipt printers, such as gift receipt/label printing. If only one printer is being used, the connector will attempt to print to the only available device if these options are selected, which may result in random characters appearing on either labels or receipts. If this occurs, please check the settings within Imagine and use only the available device.


BARCODE SCANNER

Imagine has been found to work seamlessly with both USB and Bluetooth scanners that are set to keyboard wedge mode. However, as there are numerous types of platforms, browsers, connection types, and driver requirements, K3 cannot provide an exhaustive list of the compatible scanner makes and models.


NCR SCO TRI-LIGHT

The NCR SCO tri-light requires the SCO Agent to be running to function. This can be installed by your local K3 representative or by contacting your local K3 Support.

title: Connections / Networks / Requirements
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Imagine Requirements Approved for use of URLs Whitelisted IP Address Port Numbers Supported Browsers Network Capabilities Imagine Requirements Before selecting any of our devices, we advise that you perform User Acceptance Testing since we cannot ensure that the Imagine Platform is compatible with every hardware and browser combination. A touch screen and/or a keyboard and mouse (with scroll wheel) combination are required. Windows devices with a minimum screen resolution of (1024x768) Android devices with a minimum screen resolution of (1024x768) iPhone and Android phones/small-screen devices are recommended as the minimum for K3 TOP. iPad and Android tablets are recommended as the minimum for Order Ready Board and Order Status Display. Approved for use of URLs The following URLs must be granted outbound access through any firewalls or proxies which are set up on the network. k3imagine.com k3rnd.com dddretail.com Whitelisted IP Address NOTE: In the event of email notifications failing to be delivered you may need to add the following IP to your whitelist-149.72.233.183 For more details see Email the Receipt. Port Numbers The following ports must be opened to allow traffic for certain apps and parts of Imagine to work. *For integrated card terminals there may be additional requirements beyond these ports HTTP Port 80 HTTPS Port 443 Supported Browsers Imagine is designed to work on the following browsers via Windows, Linux and OSX machines. Edge (v83.0 or later) Chrome (v80 or later) Firefox (v61 or later) Safari (v14 or later) Opera (v67 or later) The supported browsers on iOS, Android, and Windows 10 Mobile are the same. However, some functionality may be limited, such as the inability to run apps in full screen on iOS. We do not have a minimum version number requirement for these browsers on mobile devices. Although K3 provides version numbers for supported browsers on desktop machines, we recommend enabling automatic browser updates for security purposes and using the latest version of the browser whenever possible. Network Capabilities Imagine functions like any other web page on devices with a stable Wi-Fi or Ethernet connection. For devices connected to a mobile service, we recommend a stable 10Mb 4G connection or better, or at least a 3G connection. Please note that the quality of the connection affects the rendering and performance of Imagine.
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Imagine Requirements
  • Approved for use of URLs
  • Whitelisted IP Address
  • Port Numbers
  • Supported Browsers
  • Network Capabilities

Imagine Requirements

Before selecting any of our devices, we advise that you perform User Acceptance Testing since we cannot ensure that the Imagine Platform is compatible with every hardware and browser combination. 


A touch screen and/or a keyboard and mouse (with scroll wheel) combination are required.

  • Windows devices with a minimum screen resolution of (1024x768)
  • Android devices with a minimum screen resolution of (1024x768)
  • iPhone and Android phones/small-screen devices are recommended as the minimum for K3 TOP.
  • iPad and Android tablets are recommended as the minimum for Order Ready Board and Order Status Display.

Approved for use of URLs

The following URLs must be granted outbound access through any firewalls or proxies which are set up on the network.

  • k3imagine.com
  • k3rnd.com
  • dddretail.com

Whitelisted IP Address

NOTE: In the event of email notifications failing to be delivered you may need to add the following IP to your whitelist-149.72.233.183

For more details see Email the Receipt.

Port Numbers

The following ports must be opened to allow traffic for certain apps and parts of Imagine to work.

*For integrated card terminals there may be additional requirements beyond these ports

HTTP Port 80
HTTPS Port 443

Supported Browsers

Imagine is designed to work on the following browsers via Windows, Linux and OSX machines.

  • Edge (v83.0 or later)
  • Chrome (v80 or later)
  • Firefox (v61 or later)
  • Safari (v14 or later)
  • Opera (v67 or later)

The supported browsers on iOS, Android, and Windows 10 Mobile are the same. However, some functionality may be limited, such as the inability to run apps in full screen on iOS. We do not have a minimum version number requirement for these browsers on mobile devices.

Although K3 provides version numbers for supported browsers on desktop machines, we recommend enabling automatic browser updates for security purposes and using the latest version of the browser whenever possible.


Network Capabilities

Imagine functions like any other web page on devices with a stable Wi-Fi or Ethernet connection.

For devices connected to a mobile service, we recommend a stable 10Mb 4G connection or better, or at least a 3G connection.

Please note that the quality of the connection affects the rendering and performance of Imagine.

title: Assembling the Connector
text: The Connector is the HUB for all of your connections and software. Assemble the power block and insert the power cable into the DC in port on the Connector. Be sure to remove the Power Cable from the Connector by pulling the sleeve back and not by forcing the cable as this may cause damage to the cable and pins. Connect the printer to the Connector using the supplied USB cable. Connect the cash drawer to the printer using the supplied DK cable. Connect the Connector to your network (router) using the supplied network cable. Note that your network must support DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) and allow the device to be assigned an IP address that has outgoing Internet access. Press the On button to power on the Connector. Wait a few moments for the Connector to connect to the Internet. A blue LED will indicate that the Connector is powered on. Check into the K3 servers and print a status report. This report will have the IP address and Unit ID you need to add via the K3 Connector Manager. Note that when adding a new Connector and configuring it to a store, it may take up to 10 minutes to complete. When it has finished, you will receive a startup notification printout. Note that if the Startup Complete slip prints without an IP address, you should check your network settings and router. A missing IP address means the Connector has not been issued an IP address automatically. Example of a Startup Slip Example of a Startup Complete Slip
description:
The Connector is the HUB for all of your connections and software.

  1. Assemble the power block and insert the power cable into the DC in port on the Connector. Be sure to remove the Power Cable from the Connector by pulling the sleeve back and not by forcing the cable as this may cause damage to the cable and pins.

  2. Connect the printer to the Connector using the supplied USB cable.

  3. Connect the cash drawer to the printer using the supplied DK cable.

  4. Connect the Connector to your network (router) using the supplied network cable. Note that your network must support DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) and allow the device to be assigned an IP address that has outgoing Internet access.

  5. Press the On button to power on the Connector. Wait a few moments for the Connector to connect to the Internet. A blue LED will indicate that the Connector is powered on.

  6. Check into the K3 servers and print a status report. This report will have the IP address and Unit ID you need to add via the K3 Connector Manager. Note that when adding a new Connector and configuring it to a store, it may take up to 10 minutes to complete. When it has finished, you will receive a startup notification printout.

  • Note that if the Startup Complete slip prints without an IP address, you should check your network settings and router. A missing IP address means the Connector has not been issued an IP address automatically.


Example of a Startup Slip


Example of a Startup Complete Slip

title: Changing the K3 Printer Language
text: If you need to use a different language on the K3 Printer, you can follow these steps to set the language within the printer itself: Download the printer tool from https://rongtatech.com/RP820_download and connect the thermal printer to your computer. Note the COM port it connects to, which can be found in the device manager. Start up the PrinterTool.exe and configure the printer by setting the COM port to the one it's connected to and hit "Configure the port." Set the baud rate to 38400 and then hit "Set Printer." On the first tab, set the code page to "CHINESE" and set the baud rate to 38400. Hit "Set" and the printer should beep. On the "BIG5" tab, set the emulation mode to "EPSON ESC/POS" and language to "Chinese GB 18030." Hit "Set" on both options. On the first tab again, hit "Self-Test." The printer should print out its configuration, and the code page at the top should now read "GBK" along with some Chinese characters. Unplug the printer and plug it back into your connector, then reboot your connector. SSH onto the connector and change the docker-compose.yml file by adding the following configuration to the arm gateway container as an environment variable: "EncodingCodePageValue: 54936" Reboot your connector again.
description:
If you need to use a different language on the K3 Printer, you can follow these steps to set the language within the printer itself:

  1. Download the printer tool from https://rongtatech.com/RP820_download and connect the thermal printer to your computer. Note the COM port it connects to, which can be found in the device manager.
  2. Start up the PrinterTool.exe and configure the printer by setting the COM port to the one it's connected to and hit "Configure the port." Set the baud rate to 38400 and then hit "Set Printer."
  3. On the first tab, set the code page to "CHINESE" and set the baud rate to 38400. Hit "Set" and the printer should beep.
  4. On the "BIG5" tab, set the emulation mode to "EPSON ESC/POS" and language to "Chinese GB 18030." Hit "Set" on both options.
  5. On the first tab again, hit "Self-Test." The printer should print out its configuration, and the code page at the top should now read "GBK" along with some Chinese characters.
  6. Unplug the printer and plug it back into your connector, then reboot your connector.
  7. SSH onto the connector and change the docker-compose.yml file by adding the following configuration to the arm gateway container as an environment variable: "EncodingCodePageValue: 54936"
  8. Reboot your connector again.

title: Connector Issues
text: Please note that the following list is non exhaustive, and if you are still experiencing difficulties connecting, please do not hesitate to contact the relevant local support team within K3 @Support - K3 (k3btg.com). Here are some troubleshooting steps: Check the power, USB, and Ethernet connections. Make sure the correct connector is selected via the POS using the USB icon. A green bar indicates the selected connector is working as expected. A red flashing bar indicates there is a problem with the selected connector. A green dot indicates the connector is available but not selected. A red dot indicates there is an issue with the connector. Ensure everything is connected correctly. See @Installing Hardware for more information. Make sure only the supplied hardware is plugged into the connector. Note that the Wi-Fi connector on the rear of the unit should not be relied on for connectivity. We advise a hardwired connection. If the connector is being used with just a label printer alone, the label printer must still be plugged into the lower USB port. Check that the connector is plugged in, the power cable and brick are assembled correctly, and the socket is switched on. Ensure the Ethernet cable is plugged into a live socket, router, or otherwise attached to LAN. If a live Ethernet connection is not available when the connector boots, it will wait 5 minutes before defaulting to the previously cached IP, and it will continue to boot. If your connector prints the start-up slip, but you still cannot connect and the boot time has been longer than normal, we recommend you connect a screen to the connector to check it's not waiting for an IP address to be issued by DHCP. Ensure the Ethernet connection is working by using another compatible device. Make sure the receipt printer is powered on and connected via the USB/Serial Converter before booting the connector. Note that if any cables are removed while the connector is powered on, then the connector must be rebooted. Check if there is sufficient paper in the receipt printer and if the lid is closed correctly. Ensure the printer is powered on and connected via the serial cable and USB/Serial Converter. Check if the start-up slip has been printed. If it's blank, check that the paper is correctly installed into the printer. If using an Epson TM88 printer, after 90 seconds of booting up, if the start-up slip has not been printed, check the DIP switches. If the start-up slip has printed, check for the IP address. If there is no IP shown, please check your router and network setup. Check if the connector is listed in Platform Admin. You should be able to see a local IP address and a 'last seen' date. If the connector is listed but there is no IP, contact K3. If the POS is showing the connector as offline (red flashing dot), this is often a sign the certificate is not installed correctly. Please check in the Certificate Manager for your operating system for the certificate, and if necessary, re-install. Ensure the connector is set up in Admin. The ID must match the unit ID on the printed slip. Note that the hex code should be exactly 6 sets of numbers and letters and be separated by - not : as displayed on the start-up slip.
description:
Please note that the following list is non exhaustive, and if you are still experiencing difficulties connecting, please do not hesitate to contact the relevant local support team within K3 @Support - K3 (k3btg.com).

Here are some troubleshooting steps:

  1. Check the power, USB, and Ethernet connections.
  2. Make sure the correct connector is selected via the POS using the USB icon.
    • A green bar indicates the selected connector is working as expected.
    • A red flashing bar indicates there is a problem with the selected connector.
    • A green dot indicates the connector is available but not selected.
    • A red dot indicates there is an issue with the connector.
  3. Ensure everything is connected correctly. See @Installing Hardware for more information.
    • Make sure only the supplied hardware is plugged into the connector.
    • Note that the Wi-Fi connector on the rear of the unit should not be relied on for connectivity. We advise a hardwired connection.
    • If the connector is being used with just a label printer alone, the label printer must still be plugged into the lower USB port.
  4. Check that the connector is plugged in, the power cable and brick are assembled correctly, and the socket is switched on.
  5. Ensure the Ethernet cable is plugged into a live socket, router, or otherwise attached to LAN.
    • If a live Ethernet connection is not available when the connector boots, it will wait 5 minutes before defaulting to the previously cached IP, and it will continue to boot.
    • If your connector prints the start-up slip, but you still cannot connect and the boot time has been longer than normal, we recommend you connect a screen to the connector to check it's not waiting for an IP address to be issued by DHCP.
    • Ensure the Ethernet connection is working by using another compatible device.
  6. Make sure the receipt printer is powered on and connected via the USB/Serial Converter before booting the connector.
    • Note that if any cables are removed while the connector is powered on, then the connector must be rebooted.
    • Check if there is sufficient paper in the receipt printer and if the lid is closed correctly.
  7. Ensure the printer is powered on and connected via the serial cable and USB/Serial Converter.
    • Check if the start-up slip has been printed. If it's blank, check that the paper is correctly installed into the printer.
    • If using an Epson TM88 printer, after 90 seconds of booting up, if the start-up slip has not been printed, check the DIP switches.
    • If the start-up slip has printed, check for the IP address. If there is no IP shown, please check your router and network setup.
  8. Check if the connector is listed in Platform Admin. You should be able to see a local IP address and a 'last seen' date. If the connector is listed but there is no IP, contact K3.
  9. If the POS is showing the connector as offline (red flashing dot), this is often a sign the certificate is not installed correctly. Please check in the Certificate Manager for your operating system for the certificate, and if necessary, re-install.
  10. Ensure the connector is set up in Admin. The ID must match the unit ID on the printed slip. Note that the hex code should be exactly 6 sets of numbers and letters and be separated by - not : as displayed on the start-up slip.

title: Installing an Epson TM88V
text: NOTE: The full TM88v manual can be found at https://files.support.epson.com/pdf/pos/bulk/tm-t88v_hwum_en_02.pdf Cable Selection To successfully connect to an Epson TM88v printer, you will need a 9-pin female to 25-pin male serial cable. The choice of cable is critical to ensure that the printer operates correctly. If you encounter printing issues despite having the correct setup, you may need to consider swapping the cable for a different brand or make. Additionally, since the connector only offers USB ports, you will need a Serial to USB converter to establish the connection. If you require further guidance, please consult your K3 Consultant for advice. Baud Speed - Hardware Setting You will require a crosshead screwdriver to physically adjust the DIP switches. Before proceeding, ensure that the TM88v is switched off and unplugged from the main power supply. Next, locate the metal cover on the underside of the TM88v. To configure the switches, set switches 7 and 8 to the on position on DSW1, but leave the other switches across both banks unchanged. After adjusting the switches, replace the metal cover, turn the TM88v over, and reconnect the power supply. Finally, power on the TM88v. To set the baud rate of the TM88v to 38400, you will need to adjust the hardware DIP switches as described in the previous instructions. Even if the self-test/Firmware Version printout indicates that the baud speed is already set to 38400, it is recommended to follow the steps below, as the values displayed in the printout can be inaccurate. To begin, power off the TM88v and then press and hold the Feed button while powering it on. Release the Feed button once the Firmware Version page has been printed, which will display both the Baud Rate and DIP Switch settings. These values need to be verified using the remaining steps outlined below. Press the Feed button for one second or more to print the Mode Selection page. Next, quickly press the Feed button three times, then press and hold the Feed button to display the Customize Value Settings page. Press the Feed button three times quickly, then press and hold the Feed button again to show the Baud Rate page. Verify that the default and current set values match the port settings, which should be 38400bps. To change the Current Set Value, press the Feed button quickly five times (38400bps), then press and hold the Feed button for more than one second. The new baud rate will be displayed as "Saved." Finally, turn off the TM88v and turn it back on without pressing or holding the Feed button. Below is an excerpt of the Serial Interface settings for the DIP switches. Highlighted are the relevant parts for setting the Baud speed to 38400.
description:
NOTE: The full TM88v manual can be found at https://files.support.epson.com/pdf/pos/bulk/tm-t88v_hwum_en_02.pdf


Cable Selection

  • To successfully connect to an Epson TM88v printer, you will need a 9-pin female to 25-pin male serial cable. The choice of cable is critical to ensure that the printer operates correctly. If you encounter printing issues despite having the correct setup, you may need to consider swapping the cable for a different brand or make.
  • Additionally, since the connector only offers USB ports, you will need a Serial to USB converter to establish the connection. If you require further guidance, please consult your K3 Consultant for advice.


Baud Speed - Hardware Setting

  • You will require a crosshead screwdriver to physically adjust the DIP switches.
  • Before proceeding, ensure that the TM88v is switched off and unplugged from the main power supply.
  • Next, locate the metal cover on the underside of the TM88v.
  • To configure the switches, set switches 7 and 8 to the on position on DSW1, but leave the other switches across both banks unchanged.
  • After adjusting the switches, replace the metal cover, turn the TM88v over, and reconnect the power supply. Finally, power on the TM88v.









To set the baud rate of the TM88v to 38400, you will need to adjust the hardware DIP switches as described in the previous instructions. Even if the self-test/Firmware Version printout indicates that the baud speed is already set to 38400, it is recommended to follow the steps below, as the values displayed in the printout can be inaccurate.

  1. To begin, power off the TM88v and then press and hold the Feed button while powering it on.
  2. Release the Feed button once the Firmware Version page has been printed, which will display both the Baud Rate and DIP Switch settings. These values need to be verified using the remaining steps outlined below.
  3. Press the Feed button for one second or more to print the Mode Selection page.
  4. Next, quickly press the Feed button three times, then press and hold the Feed button to display the Customize Value Settings page.
  5. Press the Feed button three times quickly, then press and hold the Feed button again to show the Baud Rate page.
  6. Verify that the default and current set values match the port settings, which should be 38400bps.
  7. To change the Current Set Value, press the Feed button quickly five times (38400bps), then press and hold the Feed button for more than one second. The new baud rate will be displayed as "Saved."
  8. Finally, turn off the TM88v and turn it back on without pressing or holding the Feed button.


Below is an excerpt of the Serial Interface settings for the DIP switches. Highlighted are the relevant parts for setting the Baud speed to 38400.
